Topic.Title: Attn Don Shuper

Message.Msg: Greetings Don. I honestly don't know (and yes, you have it correct). Unless someone speaks the language or has been around it in some form or like yourself does a little sleuthing, I suspect most people have no idea that it actually means something. Even if someone knows what the exact translation is, as you're aware they also need a fairly decent knowledge of local aerospace or U.S. labor history to connect the dots. I originally used a similar ID in English, but many years ago somebody #$%$ loud enough and often enough that the wizards at Yahoo! finally disabled it one day. Post here long enough, even if it's only occasionally, and it happens to just about everybody sooner or later. Given that my "assignment" was in the evening (during the event, I never missed a shift), I decided to reflect that in a new ID and also to switch to another language I speak. It wasn't really an attempt to deceive anybody. I just thought I'd have a little fun with it and do something different. And now you know the story of how I became, vierzig_nachten ...

Message.Title: so the Airbus plane appears to have two defective pilots landing on autopilot , not advised at that airport due to geography, nothing wrong
Message.Msg: But he said the NTSB would be looking closely into "UPS's instrument approach procedures" and how it typically went about guiding a large cargo hauler to touchdown on Birmingham-Shuttleworth's Runway 18. That's the runway the UPS jet was approaching when it crashed and Sumwalt said the investigation would include a flight test at the airport in a UPS A300. Kevin Hiatt, president and chief executive officer of the Flight Safety Foundation, an Alexandria, Virginia-based international watchdog group, told Reuters in an interview on Thursday that a "full instrument" landing was not highly advisable at Birmingham-Shuttlesworth. The airport can be tricky to land at because it is nestled among hills and that is especially true of Runway 18, said Hiatt. Hiatt, a former Delta Airlines pilot, said he had touched down on the runway many times himself. "It is not a full instrument landing. You have to visually fly into that runway," he said. "Sometimes it takes nuance to land there. You have to realize that hill is there or you could come in too low."

Message.Title: Boeing is 100% at fault on the utx fire suppression system fail , Boeing should have caught the problem per flight cert.
Message.Msg: An FAA audit of Boeing's supplier control procedures was part of the production certificate for the 787. Mistakes can happen, but something like this should have been discovered during a functional test for the plane. August 26, 2011 EVERETT, WA – Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Administrator Randy Babbitt today announced that the FAA has approved production of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. At an event at Boeing’s facility in Everett, Washington, Administrator Babbitt presented Boeing executives with two certificates for the design and production of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner with Rolls-Royce engines. The first, a Type Certificate, is for the FAA’s approval of the airplane’s design. The second, a Production Certificate, allows Boeing to manufacture the 787 following a rigorous review by FAA inspectors of Boeing’s quality system, production tooling, manufacturing processes and controls, inspection methods, and supplier control procedures. from another user this shows Boeing not utx is responsible for the fire suppression system working per plan and Boeing should be admitting , not utx admitting, fault as being ultimately responsible for failure, the supplier is also responsible but only for their part, the suppression system was hooked up wrong and left the Boeing factory untested and wrong that is 100% Boeing's fault

Message.Title: Why are 787 problems newsworthy , because BOEING ALWAYS SAYS “Blame them.”
Message.Msg: Why are these problems newsworthy? Because those aircraft are 787 Dreamliners—the Boeing aircraft that is under the microscope of regulators, investors, consumers, and rival companies. According to Boeing, the two oil incidents happening within two days of each other are unrelated. While it’s pretty easy to find some commonality between both, we’ll trust Boeing for now. Also notable and to be fair, understandable, the company was quick to release a statement which pretty much said, “Blame them.” "We will work with United and General Electric to complete the appropriate maintenance and testing activities, and return the airplane to service." In other words, “we didn’t make the engine, WE DID NOT MAKE THE FIRE SUPPRESSION EQUIPMENT RIGHT BUT BOEING DID SIGN A CERTIFICATE MAKING BOEING RESPONSIBLE FOR THE FLIGHT SAFETY OF THE PRODUCT AND BOEING SHOULD BE BLAMING BOEING FOR FAILURE . THE STOCK BUYING PUBLIC AND THE PASSENGERS AND THE REGUATORS AND THE FAA IS ASSIGNING BLAME TO BOEING . Message.Title: Petition Urges Nobel Peace Prize for Manning
Message.Msg: Oslo - Private Bradley Manning, the US intelligence analyst behind the largest single leak of secret documents in American history, would be a worthy winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, according to a petition presented Monday in the Norwegian capital Oslo. Norman Solomon of US activist group RootsAction handed over a list signed by over 100,000 people, mainly from the United States, who claim that Manning helped shorten the Iraq war by leaking secret documents to WikiLeaks, Norwegian public broadcaster NRK reported. Some signatories added comments explaining why Manning deserved the award, including a Czech national who wrote: "I know you can't really do this because of (the) USA, but still. He deserves it more than (US President) Barack Obama did." Obama was a surprise winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009. Manning faces 90 years in prison. A court martial is ongoing at Fort Meade, Maryland. - any phontomfield-types being duplicitous

Message.Title: Could it be the result of the McDonnell/Douglas influence within what was once a great company Boeing?
Message.Msg: Could it be the result of the McDonnell/Douglas influence within what was once a great company? From what I hear the 787, 747 are in trouble." Boeing swallowed up MickeyD like a 1880's patent medicine capsule, and exactly like those capsules the MickeyD influence has been like a tapeworm eating this once proud company up from the inside! The 787 (Phoenix) program has been doomed from the start by it's model of outsourcing WITHOUT ACCOUNTABILITY! The 747-8i & 8F are suffering due to several factors, first, it is not as economical to run 4 engines as it is to run only 2, second the "donut" sections that were added to increase capacity have had the unexpected effect of inducing harmonic "flutter" when the "wet tail" (fuel stored in the horizontal stabilizer aux. tank) is used. Without this additional fuel storage it cannot meet it's maximum range, which was one of it's main selling points. The 747-8 Freighter variant also has to compete against its sister-line of the 777F which is more fuel efficient, and the hundreds of "retired" 747s in the boneyards that can be easily converted to freighters much cheaper than buying new, as long as you don't need the nose door

Message.Title: SF fire policy changed after runningover a survivor , ban the firefighter cams wow like hide from the failure
Message.Msg: A San Francisco Fire Department ban on video cameras now explicitly includes helmet-mounted devices that film emergency scenes, according to Chief Joanne Hayes-White. The edict comes after images taken in the aftermath of the July 6 Asiana Airlines crash at the San Francisco airport led to questions about first responders' actions, which resulted in a survivor being run over by a fire truck. Hayes-White told the San Francisco Chronicle she is concerned about the privacy of victims and firefighters TRANSLATED WE DO NOT WANT TO BE IN COURT PAYING FOR THE VICTOM WE KILLED AND WILL NOT FILM OUR DEED. AND THE EXCUSE IS BOGUS A COURT CAN BAN ANY PUBLIC DISPLAY OF THE VIDEO . "There comes a time that privacy of the individual is paramount, of greater importance than having a video," she said.

Message.Title: 777x fuselage may not be built it Everett?
Message.Msg: From an article published today(search "Boeing Production May Soon Be in Robots’ Hands" for full article Boeing reps did not comment to the Times when asked about the operations in Anacorte, Washington, just off Fidalgo Bay. However, unnamed Boeing engineers did open up to the news outlet when the topic of machine-controlled manufacturing came up. “We’ve going to introduce a whole lot of automation,” the engineer told the Times, discussing the construction of the fuselage and how it would change. Local residents are awaiting news of how Boeing will construct the different elements of the 777x, as many jobs rest on the company’s decision to stay local or scrap the concept and have the fuselage built in Japan. The 777X program is expected to begin in the coming months, by which time Boeing will have settled whether the Fidalgo Bay location, Japan, or another spot in Washington state will be the site of manufacturing. The company has plenty of regulatory favor in the area, as government officials are set to welcome the company’s new manufacturing projects with open arms.

Message.Msg: Spartacus, The hissing adders come out and do what they do. Hiss.
